required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on November 19, 2021
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Sensitivity of PDL-1-analysis From Pleural Effusion in Non-small Cell Lung Cancer
clinical_study.official_title: Sensitivity of PDL-1-analysis From Pleural Effusion in Non-small Cell Lung Cancer

collaborator.agency: Institute of Pathology, University Clinic Düsseldorf

brief_summary.textblock: This is a prospective diagnostic pilot study to create hypotheses regarding immunocytochemistry (ICC) PD-L1 analysis of pleural effusions in NSCLC patients as compared to the reference standard of PD-L1 immunohistochemistry (IHC). This comparison will be done to assess sensitivity and specificity of PD-L1 detection by ICC in pleural effusions.

primary_outcome.description: Number/prevalence of PD-L1-positive patients according to immunohistochemistry (IHC) of pleural biopsy.
Number/prevalence of PD-L1-positive patients according to immunocytochemistry (ICC) of pleural aspirate

primary_outcome.measure: PD-L1 Detection in Pleural Effusion Based on All Cases With Successful PD-L1 Analysis
primary_outcome.description: Based on all cases where PD-L1 analysis was indicated and sucessful (i.e. giving definite results), the immunocytochemistry analysis of PE was compared with the immunohistochemistry analysis of pleural tissue.Two different alternatives were calculated: PD-L1 expression with a TPS ≥50% was defined as PD-L1-positive. PD-L1 expression with a TPS ≥1% was defined as PD-L1-positive.

secondary_outcome.measure: PD-L1 Detection in Pleural Effusion Based on All Cases With Indication for PD-L1 Analysis
secondary_outcome.description: Based on all cases where PD-L1 analysis was indicated, the immunocytochemistry analysis of PE was compared with the immunohistochemistry analysis of pleural tissue.Two different alternatives were calculated: PD-L1 expression with a TPS ≥50% was defined as PD-L1-positive. PD-L1 expression with a TPS ≥1% was defined as PD-L1-positive. In both instances, cases where PD-L1 analysis could not be performed were defined as negative.

secondary_outcome.measure: Tumor Cell Detection in Pleural Effusion
secondary_outcome.description: Comparing the immunocytochemistry (ICC) analysis of pleural effusion concerning the detection of malignant tumor cells as compared to the immunohistochemistry analysis of pleural tissue. Seven cases of ICC analysis with inconclusive results were defined as negative.

arm_group.description: The population for selection of potential study participants is comprised of clinical routine patients presenting with (suspected malignant) pleural effusion. These patients must have an indication for pleural puncture. The cause and nature of the pleural effusion at this time point will be unknown in many cases. To establish this, further diagnostic procedures are required. Only patients with confirmed diagnosis of non-small cell lung cancer will be included in the data analysis.

study_pop.textblock:
The population for selection of potential study participants is comprised of clinical routine patients presenting with (suspected malignant) pleural effusion. These patients must have an indication for pleural puncture. The cause and nature of the pleural effusion at this time point will be unknown in many cases. To establish this, further diagnostic procedures are required. Only patients with confirmed diagnosis of non-small cell lung cancer will be included in the data analysis.
A patient in whom suspicion of pleural manifestation of lung cancer is not confirmed, will be considered a screening failure and thus excluded from the study.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Presence of malignant pleural effusion with indication for pleural puncture and thoracoscopy
- Confirmed diagnosis of non-small cell lung cancer according to ERS guidelines
- Written informed consent
Exclusion Criteria:
- Pregnancy and/or lactation
- Acute and life-threatening illness (instable angina pectoris, acute pulmonary arterial embolism, myocardial infarction, etc.)
- Any contraindication to undergo thoracoscopy (e.g. anticoagulation therapy which cannot be discontinued for the procedure)
- Any medical, psychological or other condition impairing the patient's ability to provide informed consent

provided_document.document_type: Study Protocol and Statistical Analysis Plan

participant_flow.recruitment_details: Clinical routine patients presenting with (suspected malignant) pleural effusion and indication for pleural puncture were considered for enrollment. Patients with confirmed malignancy of pleural effusion were actually enrolled.

group.title: Malignant Pleural Effusion
group.description: Patients with confirmed malignant pleural effusion

baseline.population: patients with confirmed diagnosis of non-small cell lung cancer

group.title: Malignant Pleural Effusion
group.description: patients with confirmed malignant pleural effusion

category.title: Native Hawaiian or Other Pacific Islander

outcome.title: PD-L1 Prevalence IHC
outcome.description: Number/prevalence of PD-L1-positive patients according to immunohistochemistry (IHC) of pleural biopsy.
outcome.population: Thoracoscopy was performed in all fifty patients. PD-L1 analysis of pleural tissue was indicated in all samples with evidence of tumor cells (n=40), excluding cases with small-cell lung cancer (n=2). Mainly due to insufficient sample material (low tumor cell count) (n=3), PD-L1 analysis could actually be performed in 35 pleural tissue cases.

group.title: Number of PD-L1-positive Samples in IHC
group.description: For the assessment of potentially therapy-relevant PD-L1 expression levels, two different threshold levels of PD-L1 expression were considered as per the differing approval status (TPS ≥50% and TPS≥1%). Regarding detection of malignancy and PD-L1-positivity, results were defined as negative where the tests were not feasible or in case of inconclusive findings.

measure.title: PD-L1 Prevalence IHC
measure.description: Number/prevalence of PD-L1-positive patients according to immunohistochemistry (IHC) of pleural biopsy.
measure.population: Thoracoscopy was performed in all fifty patients. PD-L1 analysis of pleural tissue was indicated in all samples with evidence of tumor cells (n=40), excluding cases with small-cell lung cancer (n=2). Mainly due to insufficient sample material (low tumor cell count) (n=3), PD-L1 analysis could actually be performed in 35 pleural tissue cases.

class.title: PD-L1 expression with a TPS ≥ 1% was defined as PD-L1-positive
PD-L1 expression with a TPS ≥ 50% was defined as PD-L1-positive

outcome.title: PD-L1 Prevalence ICC
outcome.description: Number/prevalence of PD-L1-positive patients according to immunocytochemistry (ICC) of pleural aspirate
outcome.population: Pleural puncture was performed in all fifty patients. PD-L1 analysis of pleural effusion was indicated in all samples with evidence of tumor cells (n=36), excluding cases with small-cell lung cancer (n=3). Mainly due to insufficient sample material (low tumor cell count) (n=7) or technical issue (n=1), PD-L1 analysis could actually be performed in 25 pleural effusion cases.

group.title: Number of PD-L1-positive Samples in ICC
group.description: For the assessment of potentially therapy-relevant PD-L1 expression levels, two different threshold levels of PD-L1 expression were considered as per the differing approval status (TPS ≥50% and TPS≥1%). Regarding detection of malignancy and PD-L1-positivity, results were defined as negative where the tests were not feasible or in case of inconclusive findings.

measure.description: Number/prevalence of PD-L1-positive patients according to immunocytochemistry (ICC) of pleural aspirate
measure.population: Pleural puncture was performed in all fifty patients. PD-L1 analysis of pleural effusion was indicated in all samples with evidence of tumor cells (n=36), excluding cases with small-cell lung cancer (n=3). Mainly due to insufficient sample material (low tumor cell count) (n=7) or technical issue (n=1), PD-L1 analysis could actually be performed in 25 pleural effusion cases.

PD-L1 expression with a TPS ≥ 50% was defined as PD-L1-positive

group.title: Sensitivity and Specificity of Tumor Cell Detection
group.description: Sensitivity and specificity of tumor cell detection in pleural effusion. Seven cases of ICC analysis with inconclusive results defined as negative.

group.title: NSCLC With Pleural Effusion
group.description: The population for selection of potential study participants is comprised of clinical routine patients presenting with (suspected malignant) pleural effusion. These patients must have an indication for pleural puncture. The cause and nature of the pleural effusion at this time point will be unknown in many cases. To establish this, further diagnostic procedures are required. Only patients with confirmed diagnosis of non-small cell lung cancer will be included in the data analysis.

certain_agreements.pi_employee: All Principal Investigators ARE employed by the organization sponsoring the study.
certain_agreements.restrictive_agreement: There is NOT an agreement between Principal Investigators and the Sponsor (or its agents) that restricts the PI's rights to discuss or publish trial results after the trial is completed.

clinical_results.limitations_and_caveats: The fact that the PE did not always yield enough material for a comprehensive immunocytochemistry evaluation including PD-L1 analysis, constitutes an important limitation, in part leading to inconclusive results regarding malignancy. This may be due to a low rate of cells scaling off from the pleural lesion and/or a low rate of migration of tumor cells into the pleural fluid.

point_of_contact.organization: Hospital Bethanien Solingen, Clinic of Pneumology and Allergology, Center for Sleep Medicine and Respiratory Care, Solingen, Germany
